The thing that makes Portal and Portal 2 classic is their witty humor and ability to reach all audiences as a puzzle game, not a skill-platformer.

The thing that makes Portal and Portal 2 great is their attention to detail. This attention is not limited to its plot development; it's in everything from world map design to animation. The way Portal is built ensures that no player will be frustrated from dying and having to retrace steps again and again, and even if you do have to retrace your steps, you have a fun time doing it. More of the details can be discovered in multiple playthroughs.

Kudos to Valve for this classic that is ahead of its time, but somehow resonates with the gamers of its era.

The best game out there.
IF your looking for a good game at a big steam sale, buy this.
This is a fps puzzle game that is as intense and immersive as it gets.
It has a amazing story and a dark and intense atmosphere that will keep players inclined till the end.
The game forces players to think outside the box, use their senses of physics and figure their way out of Aperture Laboratories, sorta like Half life, only no guns.
I would not recommend this game to anyone if he/she hasn't played portal 1, as it consists of loads of spoilers for portal 1 , and pretty much starts from where the first game was left.
It also has a co-op campaigne that can be played online or split screen and has a new feature of allowing players to make their own test chambers, so you're not bound to be bored even after you've managed to complete the singleplayer and the multiplayer game, which are themselves, big enough.

Portal 1 was a great game.  Easily one of my top 10 games of all time.  Portal 2 makes it look like a tech demo.  There's so much more here.  It's longer, it has more puzzles, more gimmicks, more characters besides the spectacular GlaDOS...  It's hugely expanded upon and...  sadly, I think this is where it stumbles a bit.  Since it's slightly less focused, it's not quite as satisfying.  Don't get me wrong, it's a great game and if you liked the first you'll love the second, but some of the puzzles felt a tiny bit...  well...  fillery to me.  Then there are a few that made me want to throw my computer against the wall in frustration.  But a good puzzle SHOULD taunt the player a bit.  The solution should be JUST out of reach.  Valve did a great job here and I'm happy with it but it feels like this is as far as they can take this concept.  I don't see Portal 3 being something the world needs after this game.

-L'idea del primo capitolo proseguita benissimo con nuove meccaniche che si integrano perfettamente nel contesto

-I comandi non danno problemi

-La trama è avvincente migliore dell'1
-I personaggi sono meglio approfonditi
-Dura più del primo
-Vi piacerà statene certi

Contro:
-Dura poche ore (sempre meglio del primo)
-Dovete giocare il primo per godervelo appieno
-E' abbastanza facile
-L'audio è in inglese

Conclusioni:
Giocate il primo. Se vi è piaciuto amerete questo. Se no non comprate il 2.
Andate a comprarvi il bundle col 2 con i saldi e tornate a ringraziarmi.

Adored Portal 1, but Portal 2 is a beautiful and story-rich but essentially badly made game.

Good bits:
 - really pretty with lots of details in each area you visit.
 - Great voice actors acting out a good story.

Quick list of grievances:
 - Stupidly easy with handholding and magic helping mechanics from start to finish.
 - One unexplained help is your magical ability to see through walls. Makes zero sense and feels like help only small children or really absentminded people would need.
 - A magical help rotates and puts you at the precise middle of each portal you go through (removing all sideways momentum in relation to the portal, so you no longer can fall into and come out of a portal at an angle)
 - No exploration allowed since you can only put the portals on pre-assigned spots, of which there are only very few. So essentially there is a straight line path for you to walk on and view the beautiful areas from. Big disappointment.
 - All puzzles are trivial because of there being only an extremely limited number of places to put your portals. So few, that to solve any puzzle, you just walk in, look around, and then almost instantly see the solution to them all.
 - The physics are broken if you don't want the annoying help. As in it no longer follows basic physics principles of the normal world thereby making some puzzles impossible. Normal physics dictate (like in Portal 1) that speed and angle going in equals you flying out with the same speed and going at the same angle. This is no longer true in Portal 2 since you only ever fly directly out the portals (again, no explanation given why the portals no longer just are two sides of the same hole). In essence this means, that if you have any sideways motion (in relation to the portal) going into a portal, your speed out will be your speed directly towards + your speed sideways to the portal, which just makes no sense.
 - So to recap the above: some puzzles are absolutely impossble if you don't let the magical help essentially play the game for you. You are only there to plop down a few portals and then let the game play itself.
 - Physics of the world is broken too. You can paint with magical speed reversing paint and put a portal on it, which sounds cool and it should be. But for some reason the portals have a border that you can hit even though logic dictates, that either you hit the ground or you fall through the portal, which is just a hole. But no, you hit a magical invisible border in stead making you just stand there in stead of bouncing up or going through the portal. Again, you need to let the game play itself to avoid this.

TL;DR:
Game has departed from the basic tenent of simply being fun with normal physics since physics no longer follow normal rules. It's so easy as to be trivial and you are not even allowed to explore the otherwise beautiful areas.

THERE ARE PORTALS!!!! Story mode is like the usual 8 hours, complicating at spots and easy on others. You have an entertaining robot that follows you all the time :D I have spent most of my time playing community test chambers becuase they use some cool mechanincs not found in the story mode. THIS GAME!!! If you haven't played Portal yet, DO IT FIRST! It's NOT that long, and it's WORTH IT because these games aren't JUST puzzle games, they're DEEP stories! Portal 2 takes place in the future, after Portal, and includes a couple new challenges that help keep the puzzles interesting... And if you actually like the challenge of testing, you can play INFINITY different user made puzzles and even MAKE YOUR OWN!!! The voice cast and script is hilarious and the connections to Half Life will make you fantasize about ways Chell and Gordon could use the portal technology! Another somewhat short game with a pretty good 2 player team testing mode! 9/10

La segunda entrega de Portal es claramente mucho mejor que la primera, bastante más larga, te da la opción de jugar una aventura cooperativa con una historia diferente a la de un player y además, el juego también te permite jugar a mapas creados por la comundidad y poder crear tu mapas para compartir con los demás.

Las características de Portal 2 son muy similares, por no decir iguales a las de la anterior entrega, lo que mejor se puede apreciar entre Portal 1 y dos, es que este último, tiene una historia mucho más desarollada y más exstensa. Además de ofrecerte más tiempo de juego te ofrece algo mas de variedad en los puzzles.

Básicamente si  te gusto Portal 1, el segundo te gustara mucho más, el precio que tiene esta bien, aunque como siempre, si tienes un poco de paciencia, estos títulos siempre los ponen por 2€ o 3€.

fun and good multi player

Dec 1

I open Steam.

I open it only to boot Paladins.

A simple task, right?

Wrong.

A shiver runs down my spine as Steam updates. The Store opens. I shakily move my mouse over to the Library icon. After a few seconds of me whimpering with the psychological strain, I click gently.

My game list loads up on the left. I drag my mouse with sheer force of will up towards Paladins. Almost there....

But no.

My eye has caught. The game. The digital experience which shall not be named.

Portal 2.

Now I'm stuck. To my horror, my mouse begins the slow descent towards it. I begin to sweat rapidly, trying to regain control of my arm, but it is no use. In a fit of panic, I grab my right arm with my left, attempting to force it upwards, but my left abandons me and joins the traitor arm in its treason. I can hear the mouse click, see the Portal 2 page come up. I now try to leave get up from my seat, but my legs are just as paralyzed with fear as I am.

The mouse hovers over the play button.
It clicks, and Portal 2 boots.

Dang it.

I'd promised myself I wouldn't play it for another 7 years, to forget about it ... but ... now that I'm here on its menu, one little level wouldn't hurt would it?

Dec 21
